Award.AwardTitle: Expanding Use of the CAT: Assessing and Improving Critical Thinking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to nationally disseminate a unique assessment tool for evaluating students' critical thinking and problem solving skills. The CAT instrument (Critical thinking Assessment Test) was developed and refined with previous NSF support in collaboration with six other diverse institutions across the country. The instrument was found to have (1) high face validity for faculty across the country in STEM and non-STEM disciplines; (2) good criterion validity; (3) good construct validity relative to learning sciences theory; (4) good reliability; and (5) cultural fairness. A subsequent NSF grant supported the development and evaluation of training methods and materials to prepare other institutions to use and score the CAT instrument on their own campus. That project was successful in establishing "proof of concept" that representatives from other institutions could be successfully trained in regional workshops to administer and lead accurate scoring workshops on their own campuses.
The current project will focus on broad national dissemination of this instrument for use with both institutions and other NSF-CCLI research projects interested in assessing improvements in students' critical thinking/real-world problem solving skills. To accomplish these goals, the project will involve four interrelated activities: (1) Expanding institutional use of the CAT instrument; (2) Expanding access to the CAT instrument for other NSF-CCLI projects; (3) Developing new electronic methods for training and providing technical support; and (4) Developing, testing, and refining new test questions to insure the continued viability of the instrument. The wide-spread dissemination of this instrument will help transform the teaching of critical thinking in STEM and non-STEM education and strengthen the educational infrastructure that prepares students for STEM careers.
In an increasingly technological and information-driven society, the ability to think critically has become a cornerstone to both workplace development and effective educational programs (AACU, 2008; Bok, 2006). Developing critical thinking skills is central to both the National Science Standards (Forawi, 2001) and the National Educational Technology Standards (International Society for Technology Education, 2003). Many NSF-CCLI projects also target improving critical thinking and real-world problem solving skills, and they need valid measures to assess progress. Despite the central importance of critical thinking in the workplace and education, existing assessment tools are plagued by problems related to validity, reliability, cultural fairness, and faculty acceptance (U.S. Department of Education, 2000; Ikenberry, 2009).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project achieved its goals of broad national dissemination of the Critical thinking Assessment Test (CAT) that was developed with NSF funding to help assess and improve undergraduate education across the country.  The broader impact of this project is that over 700 participants from over 200 public and private universities and community colleges have been trained to use the CAT instrument on their campuses to engage their faculty in activities to assess and improve students' critical thinking and problem solving skills.  The participants included many minority-serving institutions including Historically Black Colleges and Universities, Hispanic Serving Institutions, and Tribal Colleges and Universities.

The CAT instrument provides opportunities for faculty to directly see and evaluate their students’ strengths and weaknesses on critical thinking and problem solving tasks that students are likely to encounter in the real world. In addition, the CAT instrument and associated training prepare faculty to develop better discipline specific course assessments that encourage students to practice and improve their critical thinking and problem solving skills.

Numerous publications in professional journals provide detailed information about studies and outcomes surrounding the CAT. Public dissemination included an award winning PBS public service announcement video that won three national awards and is currently available on YouTube and the project website (www.CriticalThinkingTest.org).  The project has supported over 95 presentations, workshops, webinars, and publications to improve our society’s understanding of how to assess and improve students' critical thinking.

The intellectual merit of this project is that the CAT instrument has been used to help researchers identify effective educational practices that improve students’ critical thinking and problem solving skills.  The project provided assistance to over 50 research projects (many funded by NSF) that used the CAT instrument to help identify effective high impact educational practices that could improve students critical thinking and problem solving skills across a variety of disciplines and educational settings.  

The project included the development of alternate test versions and numerous training materials to facilitate the use of the CAT instrument across a broad spectrum of potential applications.  In addition, the project successfully piloted machine learning (a subset of artificial intelligence) to reliably score student responses on the short answer essay questions on the CAT instrument.
